title: EPISTOLA Philip E. Hager
html:
EPISTOLA Philip E. Hager

This note acknowledges the article of Paul M. Lloyd [VERBATIM I, 5, 2] and responds to the article of Roger W. Wescott [VERBATIM I, 1]. I have long collected specific binomials which are virtually synonymous or may have been coined to appear so. In the following list of some examples many also alliterate:

{{< column >}} {{}} aches and pains {{}} {{}} alas and alack {{}} {{}} assault and battery {{}} {{}} bib and tucker {{}} {{}} bruised and battered {{}} {{}} by and by {{}} {{}} dark and dreary {{}} {{}} ditch and delve {{}} {{}} fits and snatches {{}} {{}} high and mighty {{}} {{}} hue and cry {{}} {{}} let or hindrance {{}} {{}} lo and behold {{}} {{}} look and see {{}} {{}} odds and ends {{}} {{}} over and above {{}} {{}} pick and choose {{}} {{}} rough and tumble {{}} {{}} time and tide {{}} {{}} up and doing {{}} {{}} waifs and strays {{}} {{}} wear and tear {{}} {{}} weep and wail {{}} {{}} well and good {{}} {{}} whys and wherefores {{}} {{}} wind and weather {{}} {{}} wrack and ruin {{}} {{< /column >}}

[Philip E. Hager, University of the Puget Sound]
